EN

The provided article text covers executive interviews from the FMLS:25 summit. Jonathan Fine speaks with Dor Eligula from BridgeWise about AI-powered research, highlighting blue ocean growth opportunities in Asian markets and the integration of automation with human judgment in financial analysis. Additionally, Brendan Callan, CEO of TRADU, discusses his stance against the prop trading model, arguing that it is overly dependent on fees and presents risks and confusion for retail audiences.

Key Points

  • Dor Eligula of BridgeWise discusses the rollout of AI in investment research and growth potential in Asian markets.
  • Emphasis is placed on combining automation with human judgment to prevent errors in financial analysis.
  • Brendan Callan of TRADU argues against the current prop trading model, citing fee dependence and retail risks.

Article

We start with Dor‚Äôs reaction to the Summit and then move to broker growth and the quick wins brokers often overlook. Dor shares where he sees ‚Äúblue ocean‚Äù growth across Asian markets and how local client behaviour shapes demand. We also discuss the rollout of AI across investment research. Dor gives real examples of how automation and human judgment meet at Bridgewise ‚Äî including moments when analysts corrected AI output, and times when AI prevented an error. We close with a practical question: how retail investors can actually use AI without falling into common traps. Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Brendan Callan joined us fresh off the Summit‚Äôs most anticipated debate: ‚ÄúIs Prop Trading Good for the Industry?‚Äù Brendan argued against the motion ‚Äî and the audience voted him the winner. In this interview, Brendan explains the reasoning behind his position. He walks through the message he believes many firms avoid: that the current prop trading model is too dependent on fees, too loose on risk, and too confusing for retail audiences. We discuss why he thinks the model grew fast, why it may run into walls, and what he believes is needed for a cleaner, more responsible version of prop trading. This is Brendan at his frankest ‚Äî sharp, grounded, and very clear about what changes are overdue.
